Description: The Background Worker Config stores the credentials used by the Background Worker to access the Database. An attacker could compromise the Background Worker and get access to the Database credentials.
An attacker could make a query call on the Database.
An attacker could obtain the Database credentials and use them to make unauthorised queries.

The Web Application Config stores credentials used  by the Web Application to access the Message Queue. These could be stolen by an attacker and used to read confidential data or place poisoned messages on the queue.

The data flow between the Web Application and the Background Worker is not point-to-point and therefore end-to-end secrecy cannot be provided at the transport layer. Messages could be read by an attacker at rest in the Message Queue.
Messages on the queue could be tampered with, causing incorrect processing by the Background Worker.
An attacker could put a fake message on queue, causing the Background Worker to do incorrect processing.
An attacker could generate a malicious message that the Background Worker cannot process.
An attacker could generate a malicious message that the Background Worker cannot process.
These requests are made over the public internet and could be intercepted by an attacker.
These requests are made over the public internet and could be intercepted by an attacker.
These requests are made over the public internet and could be intercepted by an attacker.

An attacker could intercept the Database queries in transit and obtain sensitive information, such as Database credentials, query parameters or query results (is unlikely since the data flow is over a private network).
